Dear Sheffield City Council,
I am requesting the following information under the Freedom of Information Act 2000. If any information is unavailable, exempt, or beyond time/cost limits, please disregard these and provide the rest.
1. Are you on a green/renewable energy tariff for gas and electricity supplies? Please answer individually for both.
2. Do you have any renewable energy installations at council-owned properties (both residential and commercial council-owned properties)?
If yes, please list them and include their maximum capacity. Options might include:
- Solar panels
- Solar thermal panels
- Wind turbines
- Air source heat pump
- Ground source heat pump
- Biomass systems
- Hydroelectric systems
- Other (please specify)
3. What percentage of commercial council-owned properties have solar panels installed as of 2024 (if this year of data is unavailable, please provide the percentage of commercial council-owned properties that have solar panels installed as of 2023)?
4. What percentage of residential council-owned properties have solar panels installed as of 2024 (if this year of data is unavailable, please provide the percentage of residential council-owned properties that have solar panels installed as of 2023)?
5. What percentage of council-owned properties (both residential and commercial council-owned properties) are powered 100% by sustainable energy as of 2024 (if this year of data is unavailable, please provide the percentage of council-owned properties that are powered 100% by sustainable energy as of 2023)?
6. Do you have any fully electric vehicles in your fleet for staff use (excluding hybrids)? If yes, how many?
7. Do you currently employ a staff member whose primary responsibility is overseeing the implementation of sustainability strategies, such as a “Sustainability Officer”?
8. What eco-friendly initiatives are implemented across your council-owned properties for your staff members to take part in? These could include green transport solutions (e.g. bike schemes), recycling programs, etc. Please describe them.
9. What were the estimated annual savings on energy bills from using renewable energy sources for the 2023 calendar year in GBP?
10. How much energy was sold back to the National Grid annually from your renewable installations for the 2023 calendar year in kWh and GBP?
Please let me know if you have any questions or require additional clarification.
Yours faithfully,
Jamie Dixon

Dear Jamie Dixon,
Thank you for your request for information relating to council solar
energy data which we received on 11/06/2024.
Please find Sheffield City Council’s response to your request set out
below:
1. Are you on a green/renewable energy tariff for gas and electricity
supplies? Please answer individually for both. No for both.
2. Do you have any renewable energy installations at council-owned
properties (both residential and commercial council-owned properties)?
Residential - Yes:  PV Panels (Solar Panels) Air Source Heat Pumps, Heat
Recovery Systems
Corporate Estate - Moor Market and Acres Hill Store.
If yes, please list them and include their maximum capacity. Options might
include:
- Solar panels Moor Market 12.8kWp and Acres Hill 20kWp
- Solar thermal panels
- Wind turbines
- Air source heat pump Acres Hill Store 3 x Mitsubishi 42.6 kW = 127.8kW
- Ground source heat pump
- Biomass systems
- Hydroelectric systems
- Other (please specify)
3. What percentage of commercial council-owned properties have solar
panels installed as of 2024 (if this year of data is unavailable, please
provide the percentage of commercial council-owned properties that have
solar panels installed as of 2023)? Less than 0.5%
4. What percentage of residential council-owned properties have solar
panels installed as of 2024 (if this year of data is unavailable, please
provide the percentage of residential council-owned properties that have
solar panels installed as of 2023)? 111 properties (0.29% of all SCC
residential properties)
5. What percentage of council-owned properties (both residential and
commercial council-owned properties) are powered 100% by sustainable
energy as of 2024 (if this year of data is unavailable, please provide the
percentage of council-owned properties that are powered 100% by
sustainable energy as of 2023)?
Residential - None
Corporate - None
6. Do you have any fully electric vehicles in your fleet for staff use
(excluding hybrids)? If yes, how many? We currently have 78, full electric
vehicles within our fleet for staff use only.
7. Do you currently employ a staff member whose primary responsibility is
overseeing the implementation of sustainability strategies, such as a
“Sustainability Officer”?
Yes
8. What eco-friendly initiatives are implemented across your council-owned
properties for your staff members to take part in? These could include
green transport solutions (e.g. bike schemes), recycling programs, etc.
Please describe them.
Cycle Scheme
Cyclescheme is an employee benefit that saves employees up to 42% on a
bike and accessories. You pay nothing upfront, and the payments are taken
tax efficiently from your salary by your employer.
Car Club
Enterprise Car Club provides pay-as-you-go, low emission cars at street
locations in the city centre and Hunters Bar. Easy to use, once registered
you reserve your car online or with their app. Enterprise Car Club takes
care of the maintenance, cleaning, tax, administration, and fuel – so you
only need to take care of the driving.
Discounted Stagecoach Bus and Tram Tickets
As a Council employee you can get money off bus and tram travel in
Sheffield and beyond by using the Stagecoach Bus App.
A discount of about 5% is available on:
• weekly tickets
• 28-day tickets
E-learning
People, Prosperity, Planet: Part 1 - An Introduction to the Climate
Emergency in Sheffield
By the end of this e-learning course, you will be able to:
• define the climate emergency
• define some common climate terminology
• begin to identify some ways you can contribute as an individual
employee to reduce the carbon footprint of the organisation and city
and increase Sheffield’s climate resilience
This e-learning is the first of two courses that aim to educate employees
and elected members on what the climate emergency is and how it’s
impacting Sheffield. The e-learning includes written text, audio and video
content as well as some interactive activities such as click and drag, or
multiple-choice questions.
People, Prosperity, Planet: Part 2 - Your Role in Our Climate Action
By the end of this e-learning course, you will be able to:
• list the ways in which the organisation is responding to the climate
emergency
• recognise the roles and responsibilities of councillors, managers, and
employees in contributing to Sheffield's climate action
• identify some ways you can contribute as an individual employee to
reduce the carbon footprint of the organisation and city and increase
Sheffield's climate resilience
This e-learning is the second of two courses that aim to educate employees
and elected members on the Council’s climate action, and the roles and
responsibilities everyone can play in helping the organisation and city to
be net zero by 2030.
The e-learning includes written text, audio, and video content as well as
some interactive activities such as click and drag, or multiple-choice
questions.
Electric Car Benefit Scheme
HR scheme to help employees choose more active or less polluting ways to
travel. A salary sacrifice scheme that gives you an opportunity to drive a
brand-new, zero emission electric vehicle.
Regular reference in corporate newsletters
[1]Climate change and what you can do | Sheffield City Council
9. What were the estimated annual savings on energy bills from using
renewable energy sources for the 2023 calendar year in GBP?
– Moor Market = £3476.00 (based on 33.5236 pence per kWh) & Acres Hill =
£7489.42 (based on 39.418 pence per kWh)
10. How much energy was sold back to the National Grid annually from your
renewable installations for the 2023 calendar year in kWh and GBP?
From the install of Solar PV at Moor Market/Acres Hill none. 100% used on
site
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.

If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your
request, you are entitled to have this reviewed. You can ask for an
internal review by replying to this email. Internal review requests should
be submitted within 40 working days from the date of this response.
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see

https://ico.org.uk/make-a-complaint/offi...
for further details.
Kind Regards,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ
